Author: greendestiny
Content: A PhD is really a lot of grind especially at the end. I don't think you can really do both a startup and a PhD well at the same time. You can't really do either without a reasonable level of commitment so if your heart is with the start-up I say go with it. \n\nAs for the chicks... I've gotta say they dig the title Dr...

Author: akkartik
Content:
Depends on how far along the PhD he is.

The social argument was bizarre, I agree. Campuses are great places to meet new people; most of my friends agree that starting work is socially a step down. And they're at least working for large corporations with lots of people in them. Working insane hours at a startup it's unrealistic to expect your social life to be an improvement relative to *anything*.

Author: henning
Content: I take it this place is basically startup/tech entrepreneurship-related stuff rather than being like programming.reddit.\n\nGreat, another social news site I'll check compulsively.

Author: ninwa
Content: It's brave to drop everything you've been working so hard for in sights of opportunity, but is it really in the electronic part search market? Sorry, I don't mean to sound negative, but a PhD in physics would have opened such a large expanse of possibilities. You're going to throw it away for a chance at more women and on the whim of one man (PG's) advice. \n\nBest of luck.

Author: thinman
Content: Holy smokes! I've been looking for something like this for ages! rawk

Content: I really like they way this website is set up.
